Caste plays a significant role in Hinduism, particularly in traditional Indian society. The caste system divides people into social groups based on their birth or occupations, and these groups are known as varnas. The four main varnas are Brahmins (priests and scholars), Kshatriyas (warriors and rulers), Vaishyas (merchants and farmers), and Shudras (manual laborers).

The caste system is deeply rooted in Hindu tradition and is practiced in various ways across different sects. Vaishnavism, for example, has been more open to social mobility than some other sects, and some Vaishnavites have claimed that caste distinctions do not matter in the eyes of God. Shaivism has traditionally relied on the Brahmins to perform religious rituals and ceremonies, while Shaktism has supported the position of women in society, providing a sense of empowerment to women from lower castes.

Smartism, in its philosophical aspect, argues that caste is irrelevant to spiritual progress, while the Hare Krishna movement has been open to people of all castes and backgrounds. The movement's founder, Swami Prabhupada, rejected the caste system and emphasized the importance of spiritual attainment rather than birth status.

In recent years, there has been a growing movement in India to reject the caste system altogether and promote equality and social justice. Despite this, caste remains a significant part of Indian society, and it is something that the country is still largely grappling with.
